questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of fever, urinary frequency, and lower back pain for the last 3 days. During this period, he has also had pain with the 3 times he has defecated. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. His father died of colon cancer at the age of 67 years. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 14 years and drinks alcohol occasionally. His temperature is 39.1째C (102.3째F), pulse is 114/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild suprapubic pain on deep palpation and a swollen, tender prostate. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 15.4 g/dL, leukocyte count is 18,400/mm3, and platelet count is 260,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transrectal ultrasonography (TRUS) is used as an aid in the diagnosis of prostate abscess, which may occur as a complication of ABP, although mainly in immunosuppressed or diabetic individuals. TRUS may be performed to rule out abscess if digital rectal examination (DRE) shows fluctuation of the prostate or if there is no clinical response to the initiated antibiotic therapy within 7 days. TRUS may also be conducted while obtaining prostate biopsies to confirm prostate cancer in patients with a suspicious DRE. Although this patient's swollen prostate and urinary frequency may be consistent with prostate cancer, a painful prostate and fever are not. Lower back pain and/or pain on defecation could occur as a result of advanced metastatic prostate cancer, but this patient's DRE would show a large uneven nodule.

B) INCORRECT:

While an elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) can indicate prostatitis, it is not diagnostically significant because of high false-positive rates; in addition, it cannot confirm the underlying etiology. Serum PSA can also be elevated in conditions like prostate cancer, benign prostatic hyperplasia, or even after a digital rectal examination. Measuring PSA to screen for prostate cancer is controversial but is generally not routinely recommended; patients at increased risk may opt for PSA screening anyway after a shared decision-making process. Regardless, although this patient's swollen prostate and urinary frequency may be consistent with prostate cancer or benign prostatic hyperplasia, a painful prostate and fever are not. Lower back pain and/or pain on defecation could occur as a result of advanced metastatic prostate cancer, but this patient's DRE would show a large uneven nodule.

C) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is commonly used to treat infections with gram-positive bacteria. Although this patient would benefit from prompt antibiotic administration, most cases of ABP are due to gram-negative organisms, which vancomycin is not effective against. Instead, ciprofloxacin and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole are examples of common first-line empiric antibiotics used to treat ABP because of their bacterial coverage and ability to cross the blood-prostate barrier.

D) CORRECT:

Signs of infection (fever, urinary frequency) along with a swollen, tender prostate are sufficient to establish the diagnosis of acute bacterial prostatitis. A urine culture should be performed to determine the causative organism and guide antimicrobial treatment. Antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should be started empirically and then tailored to the urine culture susceptibility reports once available. Treatment for 6 weeks is recommended for eradication.

E) INCORRECT:

Urethral swab and culture can be used to rule out urethritis due to sexually transmitted pathogens (e.g., chlamydia). This patient has fever and uses condoms inconsistently, however, the absence of dysuria, burning/itching of the urethral meatus, and urethral discharge make urethritis unlikely. His low back pain and tender prostate are more consistent with ABP, which requires another initial test.

F) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin is an alpha-1 receptor antagonist commonly used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Although this patient's swollen prostate and urinary frequency may be consistent with BPH, a tender prostate, lower back pain, pain on defecation, and fever are not. While tamsulosin can be used in acute bacterial prostatitis to aid micturition, especially in men with voiding symptoms, it is used as adjunctive therapy. Tamsulosin is more commonly used in chronic prostatitis.
questions.hint: The patient has a fever, lower back pain, symptoms of acute bladder irritation (urinary frequency), and a swollen, tender prostate, which is consistent with acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP).

questions.text:
A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of diffuse perineal and scrotal pain. On a 10-point scale, he rates the pain as a 5 to 6. He reports that during this time he also has pain during ejaculation and dysuria. He did not have fever. The pain is persistent despite taking over-the-counter analgesics. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He appears healthy and well nourished. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal and scrotal examination shows no abnormalities. Rectal examination shows a mildly tender prostate without asymmetry or induration. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
5000/mm3



Platelet count
320,000/mm3



Urine



RBC
none


WBC
4-5/hpf


A urine culture is negative. Analysis of expressed prostatic secretions shows 1 WBCs/hpf (N <10). Scrotal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with a prostatic abscess are acutely ill, presenting with spiking fever, chills, dysuria, perineal pain, and an enlarged, severely tender, boggy/fluctuant, prostate on digital rectal examination. In addition, urinalysis in prostatic abscess would show numerous WBCs and bacteria. Although this patient also presents with dysuria and perineal pain, the chronicity of his symptoms, absence of fever, minimal tenderness of the prostate on examination, and no evidence of inflammation/infection on analysis of his urine/prostatic secretions make the diagnosis of prostate abscess highly unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) can manifest with dysuria (irritative urological symptoms). However, perineal/scrotal pain and pain on ejaculation and a normal prostate size are not features of BPH, suggesting an alternative diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CPPS) is an idiopathic condition characterized by pelvic pain/discomfort for at least 3 months, often accompanied by symptoms of bladder irritation (urinary frequency, urgency) in the absence of an identifiable cause. Sexual dysfunction, such as pain during ejaculation and erectile dysfunction as well as a slightly tender prostate on examination can also be associated with CPPS. Constitutional symptoms are commonly absent. CPPS is a diagnosis of exclusion that should be considered if all diagnostic tests show no abnormalities.

See "Overview of clinical features of bacterial prostatitis and chronic pelvic pain syndrome" table.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with chronic bacterial prostatitis (CBP) typically present with symptoms of bladder irritation (urinary frequency, dysuria), which may be accompanied by lower abdominal or perineal pain. Rectal examination in patients with CBP is usually normal but can show an enlarged, slightly tender, and/or indurated prostate. However, unlike this patient's normal findings, urinalysis, urine culture, and analysis of expressed prostatic secretions in CBP would show evidence of infection (i.e., leucocyturia, bacteriuria, positive urine culture).

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with advanced prostate cancer may present with bladder complaints and, if there is perineural invasion, pelvic pain. However, tumors large enough to invade adjoining tissues would likely be palpable on digital rectal examination (prostate cancer most often occurs in the peripheral zone of the prostate that is palpable on DRE). As this patient has a normal prostate on DRE, it is very unlikely that prostate cancer is the cause of his symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with chronic epididymitis typically present with discomfort and/or pain in the scrotum, testicle, or epididymis for > 6 weeks. This condition is a rare diagnosis that can have an infectious or noninfectious cause. On examination, patients may have a thickened epididymis. This patient's normal scrotal examination and ultrasound, mild prostate tenderness on palpation, and pain during ejaculation make another diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: This patient presents with persistent pelvic pain, irritative urological complaints, and painful ejaculation, despite normal examination results (negative urine culture, normal analysis of expressed prostatic secretions).

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of urinary frequency and perineal pain for the past 3 days. During this time, he has also had pain with defecation. He is sexually active with his wife only. His temperature is 39.1째C (102.3째F). His penis and scrotum appear normal. Digital rectal examination shows a swollen, exquisitely tender prostate. His leukocyte count is 13,400/mm3. A urine culture obtained prior to initiating treatment is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rods in pink colonies
Gram-negative, oxidase-positive rods in green colonies
Gram-negative, encapsulated rods in mucoid colonies

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

E. coli is a gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rod that grows in pink colonies on MacConkey agar. E. coli is the most common etiology of acute bacterial prostatitis in men older than 35 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative rod that grows in green colonies. The green color is due to the bacteria production of pyoverdin and pyocyanin (green/blue pigments). P. aeruginosa can cause multiple conditions, including pneumonia, skin infections, and nosocomial infections. Although P. aeruginosa can cause acute bacterial prostatitis, it is not the most common etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella species are gram-negative rods that grow in mucoid colonies. This mucoid consistency is due to the highly capsulated nature of the bacteria, and it helps to distinguish it from other lactose fermenters on MacConkey agar. Klebsiella pneumoniae causes pneumonia and UTIs in immunocompromised patients, while Klebsiella granulomatis is a sexually transmitted infection that causes a painless ulcer. Although Klebsiella can cause acute bacterial prostatitis, it is not the most common etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia species are weakly staining, obligate intracellular bacilli that do not grow on artificial media. Chlamydiae can cause acute bacterial prostatitis in younger, sexually-active men. However, this patient is over 35 years of age with a low-risk sexual history. A different etiology is more likely to be the cause of his acute bacterial prostatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae are gram-negative, aerobic, intracellular diplococci. This pathogen does not grow on common blood agar but instead requires Thayer-Martin agar, which prevents overgrowth of other flora. N. gonorrhea can cause acute bacterial prostatitis in younger, sexually active men. However, this patient is over 35 years of age with a low-risk sexual history. A different etiology is more likely to be the cause of his acute bacterial prostatitis.
questions.hint: Fever, increased urinary frequency, and a swollen, tender prostate are consistent with acute bacterial prostatitis. Given this patient's age and lack of risk factors, the most likely infectious agent is Escherichia coli.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 55 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: White, self-identified
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: I have back pain and have needed to pee frequently for the past 5 days.
History of Present Illness:


lower back pain for 5 days

constant pain; rated 7/10
associated fever over the past 3 days

reports increased urinary frequency


Past Medical History:

urinary tract infection 2 weeks ago; 7-day course of oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole was initiated at the time, which he completed
benign prostatic hyperplasia: underwent a transurethral prostatic resection 3 weeks ago

3-year history of hypertension

Medications:
enalapril
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
noncontributory
Psychosocial History:

does not smoke (previously smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 14 years)
drinks alcohol occasionally

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


39.1째C(102.3째F)
114/min
18/min
140/90 mm Hg
98%
165 cm(5 ft 5 in)
85 kg(187 lbs)
31.2 kg/m2




Appearance: sitting forward at the edge of a hospital bed; uncomfortable
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: S1 and S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: mild suprapubic pain on deep palpation
Rectal: swollen, mildly tender prostate without induration
Extremities: symmetrically cool; no edema
Neurologic: alert and oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal neurologic deficits

Diagnostic Studies


Blood



Hemoglobin
15.4 g/dL


WBC
18,400/mm3



Platelet count
260,000/mm3



Urine



WBC
45/hpf


RBC
Negative


Culture
Pending



Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, is used to treat respiratory infections, infections caused by atypical pathogens, and certain sexually transmitted infections. Azithromycin is also one of the preferred treatment options for chronic bacterial prostatitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Ureaplasma because of its bacterial coverage and ability to cross the blood-prostate barrier. However, given this patient's acute clinical presentation and recent urological procedure, an antibiotic with coverage against gram-negative bacteria is more appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Tetracyclines such as doxycycline are primarily used to treat infections caused by atypical or intracellular pathogens such as Chlamydia spp. and Borrelia spp. Doxycycline is also recommended as a single agent in chronic bacterial prostatitis and in combination with ceftriaxone in ABP if a sexually transmitted infection (STI) is suspected (i.e., in sexually active men < 35 years of age, men > 35 years of age who engage in high-risk sexual behaviors). Given this patient's clinical presentation, absence of risk factors for STIs, and recent urological procedure, an antibiotic with coverage against gram-negative bacteria is more appropriate.

C) CORRECT:

ABP is most commonly caused by Escherichia coli (E. coli), which can occur after genitourinary tract interventions such as transurethral prostatic resection. Inpatient treatment should be considered for patients with risk factors such as systemic symptoms (e.g., fever) and recent prostatic manipulation. IV fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin) or beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam or third-generation cephalosporin), with or without an aminoglycoside, are used for empiric antibiotic treatment because of their coverage against gram-negative bacteria and ability to cross the blood-prostate barrier. Once urine culture susceptibility reports are available, treatment is tailored accordingly. Treatment duration in severe infections is 46 weeks and infection resolution should be confirmed with repeat urine culture 1 week after treatment completion.

D) INCORRECT:

Second-generation cephalosporins such as cefuroxime have a broad spectrum of activity encompassing many gram-positive and some gram-negative bacteria. ABP, especially following a transurethral urological procedure, is most commonly caused by gram-negative bacteria. Therefore, an antibiotic with broader coverage against gram-negative bacteria that can cross the blood-prostate barrier is more suitable for empiric treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is commonly used to treat infections caused by gram-positive bacteria. Given this patient's acute clinical presentation and recent urological procedure, an antibiotic with coverage against gram-negative bacteria is more appropriate.
questions.hint: Fever, lower back pain, acute bladder irritation (i.e., urinary frequency), and a swollen, tender prostate is consistent with acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP).

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents to the hospital with a 4-day history of perineal pain, fever, and malaise. Two weeks earlier, he presented with urinary frequency, perineal pain, and a tender prostate; urine culture grew Escherichia coli susceptible to ciprofloxacin, and he was started on oral ciprofloxacin. He initially felt better; however, 4 days ago, while still on antibiotics, he developed fevers and recurrent perineal pain.
His temperature is 38.6째C, his heart rate is 100 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 111/85 mm Hg. He has pain with palpation in the suprapubic region, and his prostate is tender and boggy on digital rectal examination.
He is started on intravenous saline.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Perform prostatic massage to collect secretions for culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Initiating intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam is not warranted; antibiotic resistance is unlikely, given that the E. coli in the patients urine culture was susceptible to ciprofloxacin.

B) INCORRECT:

Both ciprofloxacin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole have good penetration into the prostate. Switching from ciprofloxacin to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is not indicated, because failure of appropriate therapy to relieve symptoms is most likely due to a need for abscess drainage, rather than poor antibiotic penetration.

C) INCORRECT:

Urodynamic testing is useful in the evaluation of chronic prostatitis and chronic pelvic pain syndrome, not acute prostatitis.

D) CORRECT:

Prostatic abscess is a rare but serious complication of acute prostatitis. It is more common in immunocompromised patients. It should be suspected in patients who do not improve after initial antibiotic therapy or in those who initially improve and then deteriorate. The organisms that most commonly cause prostatic abscesses are Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus. Diagnosis is made by transrectal ultrasonography or, on occasion, CT. Draining the abscess is essential.

Key learning point: Patients with acute prostatitis who deteriorate after initiation of antibiotic therapy should undergo transrectal ultrasonography to evaluate for prostatic abscess.

E) INCORRECT:

Performing prostatic massage is contraindicated during an episode of acute prostatitis because of the risk of bacterial dissemination.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents for further management of intermittent discomfort in his pelvis, testicles, and perineum. The symptoms have been present for about 8 months and range from mild discomfort to moderate pain that occurs on most days of the week and varies throughout the day. The patient also notes intermittent mild dysuria and a sense of incomplete bladder emptying. He has no weight loss, depression, bowel abnormalities, or history of abdominal surgery. He is taking no medications and has a history of an urticarial rash with a sulfonamide antibiotic.
Two months ago, the patient was evaluated for these symptoms by a urologist, whose examination of the abdomen, prostate, and genitalia was normal. Urinalysis and urine culture were negative, and office ultrasound revealed no postvoid urinary residual. A 6-week course of ciprofloxacin was prescribed by the urologist but was ineffective.
At today's visit, an examination of the abdomen, spine, hips, prostate, and genitalia is normal, and there is no evidence of inguinal hernia. Urinalysis remains normal.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiinflammatory drugs may relieve discomfort in some patients with chronic pelvic pain syndrome. However, they are usually considered second-line if antibiotics and/or alpha-blockers are ineffective. Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs such as celecoxib are usually chosen instead of glucocorticoids because of their more favorable side-effect profile.

B) INCORRECT:

Oxybutynin is an anticholinergic agent that is used to treat overactive bladder. This patient does not have typical overactive bladder symptoms, such as urgency, urge incontinence, and urinary frequency.

C) INCORRECT:

Some clinicians prescribe antibiotics for men with chronic pelvic pain syndrome, even when evidence for bacterial infection is absent. This patient has already received a 6-week course of ciprofloxacin, with no effect; prescribing another course of the same (or another) antibiotic is not recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Some clinicians prescribe antibiotics for men with chronic pelvic pain syndrome, even when evidence for bacterial infection is absent. This patient has already received a 6-week course of ciprofloxacin, with no effect; prescribing another course of the same (or another) antibiotic is not recommended.

E) CORRECT:

This patients presentation chronic discomfort in the pelvic or genital region, with nonspecific urinary symptoms and no confirmation of infection is consistent with chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CPPS); sometimes this term is used interchangeably (or in conjunction with) chronic nonbacterial prostatitis, but the role of prostatic inflammation or infection in CPPS is unclear.

Alpha-blockers, antibiotics, and antiinflammatory drugs are commonly prescribed for patients with CPPS. Randomized trials with these agents have yielded varying results, and no one agent has emerged as consistently effective. Many experts consider a therapeutic trial with an alpha-blocker such as alfuzosin to be a reasonable first-line approach especially in patients who have voiding symptoms in addition to pelvic discomfort. These agents are usually well tolerated and safe in otherwise healthy men. Although this patient previously had an urticarial rash with a sulfonamide antibiotic, there is no evidence to suggest that there is allergic cross-reactivity between sulfonamide antibiotics and nonantibiotic sulfonamides.

Some clinicians prescribe antibiotics for men with CPPS, even when evidence for bacterial infection is absent. This patient has already received a 6-week course of ciprofloxacin, with no effect; prescribing another course of the same (or another) antibiotic is not recommended.

Antiinflammatory drugs may relieve discomfort in some patients with CPPS. However, they are usually considered second-line if antibiotics and/or alpha-blockers are ineffective. Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs such as celecoxib are usually chosen instead of glucocorticoids because of their more favorable side-effect profile.

CPPS is often associated with psychosocial comorbidities including depressive symptoms and anxiety that may require multidisciplinary attention.

Key learning point: After a 6-week course of ciprofloxacin, the most appropriate management approach for a man with pain and lower urinary tract symptoms related to chronic pelvic pain syndrome is a trial of an alpha-blocking agent such as alfuzosin.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with type 2 diabetes reports an 8-hour history of fever, chills, urinary frequency, and dysuria. He also notes pain in his lower abdomen and behind his scrotum.
On examination, his temperature is 38.7째C. There is no tenderness to palpation, guarding, rebound in the abdomen, or distention of the urinary bladder. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness to percussion. Examination of the testicles is unremarkable. The prostate is swollen and tender.
Urinalysis reveals 51 to 100 white cells per high-power field (reference range, 02).
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin, which improves urine flow rates in benign prostatic hyperplasia, is not used to treat acute bacterial prostatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen is not used to treat acute bacterial prostatitis.

C) CORRECT:

Acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP), which is characterized by symptoms of a urinary tract infection, is likely caused by infected urine ascending to the intraprostatic ducts. Patients describe pain in the perineum, scrotum, or testicles and can have a history of urinary tract infection. Type 2 diabetes is a risk factor for the development of ABP. Digital rectal examination findings include diffuse prostate swelling and tenderness to palpation, related to acute inflammation.

In severe cases of ABP, parenteral administration of a fluoroquinolone, a third-generation cephalosporin, or a broad-spectrum penicillin derivative with or without an aminoglycoside is recommended. Less-severe cases can be treated with oral fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, which have excellent prostate penetration and activity against usual pathogens, including Pseudomonas. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is also a reasonable choice for empiric therapy for ABP. The treatment course is typically 2 to 4 weeks. Although most cases of acute prostatitis are caused by gram-negative bacteria, a urine culture is mandatory just before starting empiric antibiotics to help guide treatment in cases of atypical organisms.

Key learning point: The most appropriate empiric treatment for a patient with symptoms and signs of acute bacterial prostatitis is an oral fluoroquinolone, such as ciprofloxacin.

D) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin and doxycycline should be reserved for special indications, such as treating prostatic infections associated with Chlamydia.

E) INCORRECT:

Nitrofurantoin, although commonly used for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections in women, has poor prostatic tissue penetration and the potential for significant adverse reactions when used for prolonged periods. Thus, it does not play a role in the treatment of acute bacterial prostatitis.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman reports an 8-month history of pelvic pain. She describes the pain as a constant dull throbbing sensation in her pelvis. She is unable to identify a specific region where the pain is localized. She reports no dysuria, dyschezia, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, or heavy menstrual bleeding.
On pelvic examination, her external genitalia appear normal; bimanual examination reveals mild diffuse tenderness. No adnexal masses are palpable.
Laboratory tests  including a leukocyte count, urinalysis, tests for sexually transmitted infections, and a pregnancy test  are unremarkable.
Pelvic ultrasonography is normal.
This patients presentation is most typical of which one of the following diagnoses?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis is a common condition associated with chronic pelvic pain. However, endometriosis is more often associated with cyclical pelvic pain, heavy and painful periods, and dyspareunia; it typically presents in women younger than this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Interstitial cystitis is associated with urinary urgency, urinary frequency, and pelvic pain.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic pelvic pain is a diagnosis of exclusion referring to pain that is located in the lower abdomen and pelvis for at least 6 months, is severe enough to cause functional disability or require medical or surgical treatment, and does not have an identifiable cause.

Before this diagnosis can be made, other conditions must be ruled out through a detailed medical, surgical, and gynecologic history and a thorough physical examination. Laboratory testing and imaging should be guided by the patients symptoms and physical findings but are often less useful. Commonly performed evaluations include testing for sexually transmitted infections, pelvic ultrasound, and sometimes diagnostic laparoscopy. Involvement of other organ systems (e.g., urinary, musculoskeletal, nervous, and vascular) is common, sometimes requires further evaluation, and makes the diagnosis difficult. More than 90% of patients with chronic pelvic pain are women.

As is the case with other chronic pain syndromes of unknown etiology, management involves creating a trusting patient-provider relationship wherein a multipronged approach can be implemented. This approach may include addressing any possible physical contributors to the pain, addressing the psychological burden of disease (including insomnia, depression, anxiety, and social isolation), and recommending interventions such as:

Pelvic physical therapy
Neuropathic medications (such as serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors or gabapentin)
Referral to a pain specialist for trigger point injections and other interventional pain procedures
Complementary or alternative approaches including acupuncture, yoga, and mindfulness

Key learning point: A diagnosis of chronic pelvic pain should be considered when a patient has at least 6 months of severe pain in the lower abdomen and pelvis without an identifiable cause.

D) INCORRECT:

A bladder diverticulum is an outpouching in the bladder and is often asymptomatic. Occasionally, a bladder diverticulum can cause problems such as recurrent urinary tract infections, but it is not a typical cause of pelvic pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Vaginismus is a condition that causes pain or discomfort with intercourse but is not generally associated with other pelvic symptoms.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man is evaluated in a skilled nursing facility for a 2-day history of dysuria, urinary urgency, and incontinence. He also describes persistent pain localized to the lower abdomen and rectal area.
Three months ago, he underwent dilation of a urethral stricture, which was presumed to be related to an indwelling urinary catheter placed during a hospitalization for a heart failure exacerbation 4 months ago. He also has a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and ischemic cardiomyopathy. His current medications are carvedilol 12.5 mg twice daily, lisinopril 10 mg daily, furosemide 40 mg daily, and aspirin 81 mg daily.
He has a blood pressure of 138/74 mm Hg, a heart rate of 84 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 38.1째C. Physical examination reveals jugular venous pressure of 8 cm of water, a regular cardiac rhythm with a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex, clear lungs, a soft abdomen without tenderness to palpation, and perineal tenderness upon palpation.
In addition to routine urinalysis, which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate?

choices.text: Prostatic massage followed by culture of prostatic secretions
Urine testing for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prostatic massage followed by culture of prostatic secretions is not necessary in acute prostatitis and may carry risks including bacteremia. It is a very helpful diagnostic maneuver in the setting of suspected chronic prostatitis, in which symptoms are prolonged or recurrent.

B) INCORRECT:

Urodynamic studies can be useful for evaluating urge incontinence due to overactive bladder, which is defined as the presence of urinary urgency with or without urinary incontinence in the absence of a urinary tract infection (UTI) or other obvious pathology. Urodynamic studies are not indicated in the setting of an acute UTI, and this patient cannot be considered to have overactive bladder given his current UTI. In addition, the symptoms of overactive bladder do not tend to manifest as suddenly as this patients symptoms did.

C) INCORRECT:

Excluding sexually transmitted infections (STI) due to Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae is important in at-risk patients with suspected prostatitis. Although the risk of STI in an older resident of a skilled nursing facility is not zero, in this case, the risk factors of urethral stricture and urinary tract instrumentation strongly suggest acute bacterial prostatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Transrectal ultrasound of the prostate is not indicated for evaluating acute prostatitis. It is commonly used to guide prostate needle biopsy in suspected cases of prostate cancer and is occasionally useful as a screening study to rule out prostate abscess after failed treatment of acute prostatitis.

E) CORRECT:

This patients presentation of dysuria, urinary urgency, new urinary incontinence, and fever along with perineal tenderness to palpation is consistent with acute prostatitis. Urine culture is the first step in diagnosing acute prostatitis, which develops suddenly and is usually due to enteric gram-negative bacilli but can also be caused by gram-positive bacteria, atypical pathogens, or nonbacterial factors. The history of urinary tract instrumentation in this patient does put him at risk for nosocomial or atypical infection.

Key learning point: In an older man with irritative urinary symptoms and perineal tenderness suggesting acute bacterial prostatitis, the most appropriate initial diagnostic test is urine culture.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of fever, urinary frequency, and lower back pain for the last 3 days. During this period, he has also had pain with the 3 times he has defecated. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. Physical examination shows mild suprapubic pain on deep palpation and a swollen, tender prostate. His leukocyte count is 18,400/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?

choices.text: Prostatic massage followed by culture of prostatic secretions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transrectal ultrasonography (TRUS) is used as an aid in the diagnosis of prostate abscess, which may occur as a complication of ABP, although mainly in immunosuppressed or diabetic individuals. TRUS may be performed to rule out abscess if digital rectal examination (DRE) shows fluctuation of the prostate or if there is no clinical response to the initiated antibiotic therapy within 7 days. TRUS may also be conducted while obtaining prostate biopsies to confirm prostate cancer in patients with a suspicious DRE. Although this patient's swollen prostate and urinary frequency may be consistent with prostate cancer, a painful prostate and fever are not. Lower back pain and/or pain on defecation could occur as a result of advanced metastatic prostate cancer, but this patient's DRE would show a large uneven nodule.

B) INCORRECT:

While an elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) can indicate prostatitis, it is not diagnostically significant because of high false-positive rates; in addition, it cannot confirm the underlying etiology. Serum PSA can also be elevated in conditions like prostate cancer, benign prostatic hyperplasia, or even after a digital rectal examination. Measuring PSA to screen for prostate cancer is controversial but is generally not routinely recommended; patients at increased risk may opt for PSA screening anyway after a shared decision-making process. Regardless, although this patient's swollen prostate and urinary frequency may be consistent with prostate cancer or benign prostatic hyperplasia, a painful prostate and fever are not. Lower back pain and/or pain on defecation could occur as a result of advanced metastatic prostate cancer, but this patient's DRE would show a large uneven nodule.

C) INCORRECT:

Prostatic massage followed by culture of prostatic secretions is not necessary in acute prostatitis and may carry risks including bacteremia. It is a very helpful diagnostic maneuver in the setting of suspected chronic prostatitis, in which symptoms are prolonged or recurrent.

D) CORRECT:

Signs of infection (fever, urinary frequency) along with a swollen, tender prostate are sufficient to establish the diagnosis of acute bacterial prostatitis. A urine culture should be performed to determine the causative organism and guide antimicrobial treatment. Antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should be started empirically and then tailored to the urine culture susceptibility reports once available. Treatment for 6 weeks is recommended for eradication.

E) INCORRECT:

Urethral swab and culture can be used to rule out urethritis due to sexually transmitted pathogens (e.g., chlamydia). This patient has fever and uses condoms inconsistently, however, the absence of dysuria, burning/itching of the urethral meatus, and urethral discharge make urethritis unlikely. His low back pain and tender prostate are more consistent with ABP, which requires another initial test.
questions.hint: The patient has a fever, lower back pain, symptoms of acute bladder irritation (urinary frequency), and a swollen, tender prostate, which is consistent with acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with type 2 diabetes reports an 8-hour history of fever, chills, urinary frequency, and dysuria. He also notes pain in his lower abdomen and behind his scrotum. On examination, his temperature is 38.7째C. There is no tenderness to palpation, guarding, rebound in the abdomen, or distention of the urinary bladder. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness to percussion. Examination of the testicles is unremarkable. The prostate is swollen and tender. Urinalysis reveals 51 to 100 white cells per high-power field (reference range, 02). Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin, which improves urine flow rates in benign prostatic hyperplasia, is not used to treat ABP.

B) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen is not used to treat ABP.

C) CORRECT:

Acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP), which is characterized by symptoms of a urinary tract infection, is likely caused by infected urine ascending to the intraprostatic ducts. Patients describe pain in the perineum, scrotum, or testicles and can have a history of urinary tract infection. Type 2 diabetes is a risk factor for the development of ABP. Digital rectal examination findings include diffuse prostate swelling and tenderness to palpation, related to acute inflammation. In severe cases of ABP, parenteral administration of a fluoroquinolone, a third-generation cephalosporin, or a broad-spectrum penicillin derivative with or without an aminoglycoside is recommended. Less-severe cases can be treated with oral fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, which have excellent prostate penetration and activity against usual pathogens, including Pseudomonas.

Key learning point: The most appropriate empiric treatment for a patient with symptoms and signs of acute bacterial prostatitis is an oral fluoroquinolone, such as ciprofloxacin.

D) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin and doxycycline should be reserved for special indications, such as treating prostatic infections associated with Chlamydia.

E) INCORRECT:

Nitrofurantoin, although commonly used for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections in women, has poor prostatic tissue penetration and the potential for significant adverse reactions when used for prolonged periods. Thus, it does not play a role in the treatment of ABP.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the clinic because of a 5-day history of dysuria, fever, and pain with defecation. During this period, he has also had difficulty completely emptying his bladder. He has no bleeding or purulent discharge when passing stool. He has a history of hemorrhoids treated with hemorrhoidectomy. He is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears acutely ill. His temperature is 39.0째C (102.2째F). On physical examination, the testes and anus appear normal, and there is no urethral discharge. There is pain on palpation of the perineum. Urinalysis shows 60 WBCs/hpf. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute proctitis manifests with pain during defecation and may manifest with fever in infectious cases. Sexually transmitted infections, for which this patient has risk factors (e.g., inconsistent condom use), are a common cause. However, the absence of typical symptoms such as tenesmus, rectal bleeding, and purulent discharge makes proctitis unlikely. Additionally, dysuria and leukocytosis are not expected in acute proctitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Thrombosed external hemorrhoids can cause pain during defecation, and this patient has a history of hemorrhoids. However, they typically manifest with rectal bleeding, pruritus, and masses along the anal verge, which are not seen here. Furthermore, this patient's urinary symptoms and fever are not consistent with a thrombosed external hemorrhoid.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute urethritis manifests with dysuria and pyuria (e.g., leukocytosis on urinalysis), but burning and itching at the urethral meatus are typically present. Furthermore, pain with defecation or tenderness on perineal palpation are not features of this condition. Also, fever is uncommon in patients with acute urethritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Perianal fistulas can manifest with pain during defecation and perineal tenderness. However, they are typically accompanied by visible signs on examination, such as a painful subcutaneous mass, induration, fluctuance, or purulent discharge, none of which are observed in this patient. Furthermore, this patient's urinary symptoms and fever are not consistent with a perianal fistula.

E) CORRECT:

Acute prostatitis typically manifests with pain during defecation, perineal tenderness, dysuria, and urinalysis findings that indicate a urinary tract infection (e.g., pyuria). The most common pathogen is Escherichia coli, but in patients with risk factors for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), such as inconsistent condom use, Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae should be considered. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, supported by digital rectal examination findings of a tender, swollen prostate. STI testing is recommended for patients < 35 years of age and individuals with STI risk factors regardless of age. Treatment involves empiric antibiotic therapy for the suspected pathogen.
questions.hint: Patients with this condition typically present as acutely ill, with spiking fevers, chills, and malaise.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of diffuse perineal and scrotal pain. On a 10-point scale, he rates the pain as a 5 to 6. He reports that during this time he also has pain during ejaculation and dysuria. He did not have fever. The pain is persistent despite taking over-the-counter analgesics. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Abdominal and scrotal examination shows no abnormalities. Rectal examination shows a mildly tender prostate without asymmetry or induration. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
5000/mm3



Platelet count
320,000/mm3



Urine



RBC
none


WBC
4-5/hpf


A urine culture is negative. Analysis of expressed prostatic secretions shows 1 WBCs/hpf (N <10). Scrotal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with a prostatic abscess are acutely ill, presenting with spiking fever, chills, dysuria, perineal pain, and an enlarged, severely tender, boggy/fluctuant, prostate on digital rectal examination. In addition, urinalysis in prostatic abscess would show numerous WBCs and bacteria. Although this patient also presents with dysuria and perineal pain, the chronicity of his symptoms, absence of fever, minimal tenderness of the prostate on examination, and no evidence of inflammation/infection on analysis of his urine/prostatic secretions make the diagnosis of prostate abscess highly unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) can manifest with dysuria (irritative urological symptoms). However, perineal/scrotal pain and pain on ejaculation and a normal prostate size are not features of BPH, suggesting an alternative diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CPPS) is an idiopathic condition characterized by pelvic pain/discomfort for at least 3 months, often accompanied by symptoms of bladder irritation (urinary frequency, urgency) in the absence of an identifiable cause. Sexual dysfunction, such as pain during ejaculation and erectile dysfunction as well as a slightly tender prostate on examination can also be associated with CPPS. Constitutional symptoms are commonly absent. CPPS is a diagnosis of exclusion that should be considered if all diagnostic tests show no abnormalities.

See "Overview of clinical features of bacterial prostatitis and chronic pelvic pain syndrome" table.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with advanced prostate cancer may present with bladder complaints and, if there is perineural invasion, pelvic pain. However, tumors large enough to invade adjoining tissues would likely be palpable on digital rectal examination (prostate cancer most often occurs in the peripheral zone of the prostate that is palpable on DRE). As this patient has a normal prostate on DRE, it is very unlikely that prostate cancer is the cause of his symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with chronic epididymitis typically present with discomfort and/or pain in the scrotum, testicle, or epididymis for > 6 weeks. This condition is a rare diagnosis that can have an infectious or noninfectious cause. On examination, patients may have a thickened epididymis. This patient's normal scrotal examination and ultrasound, mild prostate tenderness on palpation, and pain during ejaculation make another diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: This patient presents with persistent pelvic pain, irritative urological complaints, and painful ejaculation, despite normal examination results (negative urine culture, normal analysis of expressed prostatic secretions).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 5-day history of dysuria, fever, and pain with defecation. He also reports difficulty completely emptying his bladder during this period. He denies bleeding or purulent discharge with stool. He has a history of hemorrhoids treated with hemorrhoidectomy. He is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears acutely ill. His temperature is 39.0째C. On examination, the testes and anus are normal, and there is no urethral discharge. There is pain on palpation of the perineum. Urinalysis shows 60 WBCs/hpf. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Perianal fistulas can manifest with pain during defecation and perineal tenderness. However, they are typically accompanied by visible signs on examination, such as a painful subcutaneous mass, induration, fluctuance, or purulent discharge, none of which are observed in this patient. Furthermore, this patient's urinary symptoms and fever are not consistent with a perianal fistula.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute proctitis manifests with pain during defecation and may manifest with fever in infectious cases. Sexually transmitted infections, for which this patient has risk factors (e.g., inconsistent condom use), are a common cause. However, the absence of typical symptoms such as tenesmus, rectal bleeding, and purulent discharge makes proctitis unlikely. Additionally, dysuria and leukocytosis are not expected in acute proctitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute urethritis manifests with dysuria and pyuria (e.g., leukocytosis on urinalysis), but burning and itching at the urethral meatus are typically present. Furthermore, pain with defecation or tenderness on perineal palpation are not features of this condition. Also, fever is uncommon in patients with acute urethritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Thrombosed external hemorrhoids can cause pain during defecation, and this patient has a history of hemorrhoids. However, they typically manifest with rectal bleeding, pruritus, and masses along the anal verge, which are not seen here. Furthermore, this patient's urinary symptoms and fever are not consistent with a thrombosed external hemorrhoid.

E) CORRECT:

Acute prostatitis typically manifests with pain during defecation, perineal tenderness, dysuria, and urinalysis findings that indicate a urinary tract infection (e.g., pyuria). The most common pathogen is Escherichia coli, but in patients with risk factors for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), such as inconsistent condom use, Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae should be considered. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, supported by digital rectal examination findings of a tender, swollen prostate. STI testing is recommended for patients < 35 years of age and individuals with STI risk factors regardless of age. Treatment involves empiric antibiotic therapy for the suspected pathogen.

Key learning point: Acute bacterial prostatitis presents with dysuria, fever, perineal pain, and a tender prostate, often accompanied by pyuria on urinalysis.
questions.hint: Patients with this condition typically present as acutely ill, with spiking fevers, chills, and malaise.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 3-day history of fever, urinary frequency, and lower back pain. He also reports pain with defecation during this period. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. On examination, there is mild suprapubic pain on deep palpation and the prostate is swollen and tender. His white blood cell count is 18.4  109/L (3.510.5). Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?

choices.text: Prostatic massage followed by culture of prostatic secretions.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urethral swab and culture can be used to rule out urethritis due to sexually transmitted pathogens (e.g., chlamydia). This patient has fever and uses condoms inconsistently, however, the absence of dysuria, burning/itching of the urethral meatus, and urethral discharge make urethritis unlikely. His low back pain and tender prostate are more consistent with ABP, which requires another initial test.

B) CORRECT:

Signs of infection (fever, urinary frequency) along with a swollen, tender prostate are sufficient to establish the diagnosis of acute bacterial prostatitis. A urine culture should be performed to determine the causative organism and guide antimicrobial treatment. Antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should be started empirically and then tailored to the urine culture susceptibility reports once available. Treatment for 2 to 4 weeks is recommended for eradication.

Key learning point: Urine culture is the initial diagnostic test for acute bacterial prostatitis to identify the causative organism and guide targeted antibiotic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

While an elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) can indicate prostatitis, it is not diagnostically significant because of high false-positive rates; in addition, it cannot confirm the underlying etiology. Serum PSA can also be elevated in conditions like prostate cancer, benign prostatic hyperplasia, or even after a digital rectal examination. Measuring PSA to screen for prostate cancer is controversial but is generally not routinely recommended; patients at increased risk may opt for PSA screening anyway after a shared decision-making process. Regardless, although this patient's swollen prostate and urinary frequency may be consistent with prostate cancer or benign prostatic hyperplasia, a painful prostate and fever are not. Lower back pain and/or pain on defecation could occur as a result of advanced metastatic prostate cancer, but this patient's DRE would show a large uneven nodule.

D) INCORRECT:

Transrectal ultrasonography (TRUS) is used as an aid in the diagnosis of prostate abscess, which may occur as a complication of ABP, although mainly in immunosuppressed or diabetic individuals. TRUS may be performed to rule out abscess if digital rectal examination (DRE) shows fluctuation of the prostate or if there is no clinical response to the initiated antibiotic therapy within 7 days. TRUS may also be conducted while obtaining prostate biopsies to confirm prostate cancer in patients with a suspicious DRE. Although this patient's swollen prostate and urinary frequency may be consistent with prostate cancer, a painful prostate and fever are not. Lower back pain and/or pain on defecation could occur as a result of advanced metastatic prostate cancer, but this patient's DRE would show a large uneven nodule.

E) INCORRECT:

Prostatic massage followed by culture of prostatic secretions is not recommended in acute prostatitis due to the associated risks, including bacteremia. It is a very helpful diagnostic maneuver in the setting of suspected chronic prostatitis, in which symptoms are prolonged or recurrent.
questions.hint: The patient has a fever, lower back pain, symptoms of acute bladder irritation (urinary frequency), and a swollen, tender prostate, which is consistent with acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with type 2 diabetes comes to your clinic with an 8-hour history of fever, chills, urinary frequency, and dysuria. He also reports lower abdominal pain and pain behind his scrotum. On examination, his temperature is 38.7째C. There is no abdominal tenderness, guarding, rebound, or bladder distention. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Testicular examination is normal. The prostate is swollen and tender on examination. Urinalysis shows 51 to 100 white blood cells per high-power field (reference range, 02). Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While ibuprofen can be used as an adjunctive therapy to manage pain in ABP, it does not treat the underlying cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitrofurantoin, although commonly used for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections in women, has poor prostatic tissue penetration and the potential for significant adverse reactions when used for prolonged periods. Thus, it does not play a role in the treatment of ABP.

C) INCORRECT:

While tamsulosin may be used in the management of ABP to alleviate obstructive symptoms, it does not address the underlying cause.

D) CORRECT:

Acute bacterial prostatitis, which is characterized by symptoms of a urinary tract infection, is likely caused by infected urine ascending to the intraprostatic ducts. Patients describe pain in the perineum, scrotum, or testicles and can have a history of urinary tract infection. Type 2 diabetes is a risk factor for the development of ABP. Digital rectal examination findings include diffuse prostate swelling and tenderness to palpation, related to acute inflammation. In severe cases of ABP, parenteral administration of a fluoroquinolone, a third-generation cephalosporin, or a broad-spectrum penicillin derivative with or without an aminoglycoside is recommended. Less-severe cases can be treated with oral fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, which have excellent prostate penetration and activity against usual pathogens, including Pseudomonas.

Key learning point: The most appropriate empiric treatment for a patient with symptoms and signs of acute bacterial prostatitis is an oral fluoroquinolone, such as ciprofloxacin.

E) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin and doxycycline can be used to treat anogenital chlamydia and prostatic infections associated with Chlamydia. They are not the treatment of choice for this patient's ABP.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of urinary tract infection, lower abdominal pain, and pain behind his scrotum, in combination with a swollen and tender prostate and pyuria, are consistent with acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of fever, chills, and severe perineal pain. He reports dysuria and urinary frequency. He has no prior urological history and takes no medications. Vital signs are BP, 130/85 mm Hg; P, 95; T, 38.7째C (101.7째F); oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Digital rectal examination shows a tender, boggy prostate. Urinalysis shows 50 WBC/hpf and moderate bacteriuria. Bladder ultrasound shows a postvoid residual volume of 60 mL. What is the most appropriate disposition for this patient?

choices.text: Discharge with tamsulosin and symptom-based follow-up
Discharge with oral antibiotics and urologic follow-up
Place a Foley catheter and admit for observation
Admit for IV antibiotics and continuous monitoring
Obtain blood cultures and CT abdomen/pelvis before disposition

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alpha blockers such as tamsulosin are used as supportive care for lower urinary tract symptoms in prostatitis but do not treat the underlying bacterial infection. Antibiotic therapy is the primary treatment for acute bacterial prostatitis and must be initiated as soon as possible based on suspected etiology and severity.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has acute bacterial prostatitis with mild severity. He lacks signs of sepsis, urinary retention, or risk factors for antibiotic resistance. Young, healthy patients with acute bacterial prostatitis can typically be managed as outpatients with oral fluoroquinolones. Close follow-up is essential to ensure clinical improvement and identify complications early.

C) INCORRECT:

Foley catheterization is relatively contraindicated in acute bacterial prostatitis due to the risk of bacteremia from urethral instrumentation through inflamed prostatic tissue. With a postvoid residual of 60 mL, this patient has no evidence of urinary retention, making catheterization unnecessary, and admission is not warranted for mild acute prostatitis without complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Inpatient management is indicated for patients with signs of sepsis, urinary retention, risk factors for antibiotic resistance, or inability to take oral antibiotics.

E) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are indicated for patients with signs of sepsis. CT imaging is not routinely performed for acute bacterial prostatitis unless complications such as prostatic abscess are suspected based on clinical course or treatment failure.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man reports a 5-month history of intermittent perineal and lower back pain, accompanied by urinary frequency and painful ejaculation. He denies fever or urethral discharge. A 4-week course of ciprofloxacin prescribed by an urgent care physician provided no relief. His vital signs are normal. The abdomen is non-tender. Digital rectal examination reveals a mildly tender, normal-sized, non-boggy prostate. Urinalysis is clear, and a subsequent urine culture shows no growth. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) can cause urinary frequency. However, it typically presents with obstructive symptoms like hesitancy and a weak stream. Significant pain, especially painful ejaculation, is not a typical feature of BPH. Furthermore, this patient is relatively young for symptomatic BPH, and his prostate was found to be normal-sized on examination, not enlarged.

B) INCORRECT:

A urethral stricture typically causes obstructive voiding symptoms, such as a weak or spraying urinary stream, incomplete bladder emptying, and straining to void. While some discomfort can occur, prominent perineal pain and painful ejaculation are not primary features. This patient's main complaints are pain-related, and his examination points to the prostate as the source of tenderness.

C) INCORRECT:

Interstitial cystitis, or bladder pain syndrome, involves chronic pelvic pain with urinary frequency and urgency, often relieved by voiding. While there is symptom overlap, this condition is much more common in women. The presence of a tender prostate and painful ejaculation in this male patient points more specifically to a prostatic origin for his symptoms rather than a primary bladder pathology.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic bacterial prostatitis can present with similar symptoms of pelvic pain and urinary frequency. However, this diagnosis is defined by recurrent urinary tract infections and documented bacteria in prostatic secretions or post-prostatic massage urine samples. This patient has a negative urine culture and no history of recurrent UTIs, making an ongoing bacterial infection unlikely. The lack of response to ciprofloxacin further argues against this diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of pelvic pain for over 3 months, combined with urinary symptoms and sexual dysfunction, is characteristic of chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CPPS), also known as chronic nonbacterial prostatitis. The diagnosis is supported by the absence of evidence of a bacterial infection, including a negative urinalysis and urine culture, as well as the failure to improve with a course of antibiotics. The finding of a tender but otherwise normal prostate on digital rectal examination is also classic for this condition. CPPS is the most common form of prostatitis. Management is often multimodal and directed at symptom relief, utilizing alpha-blockers, anti-inflammatory agents, and pelvic floor physical therapy.
questions.hint: This condition is a diagnosis of exclusion and accounts for 9095%of prostatitis cases.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic with a 3-day history of fever, chills, and perineal pain. He also reports dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency. He has a history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril. His temperature is 38.8째C (101.8째F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a soft, non-tender abdomen without costovertebral angle tenderness. A digital rectal examination shows an exquisitely tender, warm, and boggy prostate. Urinalysis shows numerous leukocytes and bacteria. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Treatment of acute bacterial prostatitis requires an antibiotic with excellent penetration into prostatic tissue and activity against common uropathogens, primarily Escherichia coli and other Enterobacteriaceae. Fluoroquinolones, such as levofloxacin or ciprofloxacin, are a first-line choice for outpatient management in hemodynamically stable patients due to their favorable pharmacokinetic profile and spectrum of activity. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is an alternative, but resistance rates are higher. Treatment duration is typically longer than for simple cystitis, usually lasting at least 24 weeks to ensure eradication of the infection from the prostate gland.

B) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline has good penetration into prostatic tissue and is often used in the treatment of chronic bacterial prostatitis, in which atypical pathogens such as Chlamydia trachomatis may be a consideration. However, for acute bacterial prostatitis, which is most often caused by enteric gram-negative rods, doxycycline is not the antibiotic of choice.

C) INCORRECT:

Nitrofurantoin is an effective treatment for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections (cystitis). However, it achieves therapeutic concentrations only in the bladder and urine. It has very poor penetration into prostatic tissue, making it an inappropriate choice for treating acute bacterial prostatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotics such as ceftriaxone are indicated for patients with acute bacterial prostatitis who show signs of sepsis, are hemodynamically unstable, or are unable to tolerate oral medications. Since this patient is hemodynamically stable and is being seen in an urgent care setting, initiating treatment with an appropriate oral agent is the most suitable approach.

E) INCORRECT:

Although amoxicillin is used for various bacterial infections, it is not a first-line agent for acute bacterial prostatitis. It has poor penetration into the prostate gland, and there is a high prevalence of resistance to amoxicillin among the gram-negative bacteria, such as E. coli, that commonly cause this infection.
questions.hint: This patient's systemic symptoms, lower urinary tract symptoms, and tender, boggy prostate suggest acute bacterial prostatitis. The choice of an antibiotic depends on its ability to penetrate prostatic tissue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic with a 3-day history of fever, chills, and perineal pain. He reports dysuria, urinary frequency, and a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. He denies any penile discharge. His past medical history is unremarkable. His temperature is 38.8째C (101.8째F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows suprapubic tenderness. On digital rectal examination, the prostate is tender, swollen, and warm. Urinalysis shows numerous leukocytes and bacteria. Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is used to treat chronic bacterial prostatitis, especially when atypical organisms like Chlamydia trachomatis are suspected. However, it is not a first-line agent for acute bacterial prostatitis, which is most commonly caused by enteric gram-negative bacteria.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitrofurantoin is an effective antibiotic for uncomplicated cystitis because it concentrates well in the urine. However, it achieves subtherapeutic concentrations in prostatic tissue, making it an inappropriate choice for treating acute bacterial prostatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin, a first-generation cephalosporin, is often used for uncomplicated urinary tract infections. However, like several other antibiotics, it does not adequately penetrate prostatic tissue and is therefore not recommended for the treatment of acute bacterial prostatitis.

D) CORRECT:

The most common causative organisms for acute bacterial prostatits are gram-negative bacteria, particularly Escherichia coli. Effective treatment requires an antibiotic with excellent prostatic tissue penetration. Fluoroquinolones, such as levofloxacin or ciprofloxacin, are recommended as first-line empiric therapy for stable outpatients due to their broad-spectrum coverage of likely uropathogens and their ability to achieve high concentrations in the prostate. Treatment is typically continued for at least 24 weeks to ensure eradication of the infection and prevent progression to chronic prostatitis or a prostatic abscess.

E) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is a broad-spectrum penicillin, but it has poor penetration into the prostate gland. Additionally, there are high rates of resistance to amoxicillin among common uropathogens like E. coli, making it a poor empiric choice for acute bacterial prostatitis.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of fever, lower urinary tract symptoms, and a tender prostate on digital rectal examination (DRE) is consistent with acute bacterial prostatitis.
